DOC.HEAD: Stock Speculator Sentenced To Work in New York Drug Clinic
DOC.TEXT: A light sentence of three years probation for admitted stock manipulator Salim B. ``Sandy'' Lewis is another sign that on Wall Street it pays to settle. Lewis pleaded guilty to three counts of securities violations rather than face trial and was sentenced Monday to work in a New York drug rehabilitation clinic and pay a $250,000 fine rather than go to prison. Some securities law experts said the term appeared fair for Lewis' crime _ jacking up the price of Fireman's Fund Corp. stock in May 1986 _ but raised the question of whether white-collar felons were being treated too leniently. In her sentencing speech, U.S. District Judge Mary Johnson Lowe told Lewis that ``your skills should not be wasted in warehousing you.'' She also said his admission of guilt was a mitigating factor. ``Where you run into problems is the kid who sells a little marijuana or cocaine and gets three years,'' said Alan Bromberg, a securities law professor at Southern Methodist University. ``I'm not sure he's doing any more social harm. It's just that he's not capable of doing as much social good.'' Lewis was ordered to work 40 hours a week for one year at Daytop Village, a Manhattan-based drug rehabilitation clinic. He must work 20 hours a week at the clinic in the second and third years of his probation. Lewis will work at Daytop as an executive consultant; the idea to work there was his. Boyd L. Jefferies, the former Los Angeles stockbroker who identified Lewis as part of a plea deal in which he cooperated with the government, in July was sentenced to five years probation and community service and fined $250,000. Two other figures in the Wall Street scandals still await sentencing after pleading guilty to securities crimes: former takeover strategist Martin Siegel and former stock arbitrager Robert Freeman. Observers said the Lewis case could bear on sentencing GAF Corp. Vice Chairman James T. Sherwin, who was convicted last week of stock manipulation in a case also before Lowe. Sherwin has done extensive work for a refugee relocation agency, as Lewis had worked with drug-addiction agencies and the poor. Lewis, 50, a prominent Wall Street veteran, had faced up to 15 years in prison and a $750,000 fine. His firm, S.B. Lewis & Co., was fined $400,000 for violating federal securities laws. The stock manipulation raised the value of Fireman's Fund stock immediately before a longtime Lewis client, American Express Co., sold a large amount of shares in a new public offering. American Express _ which invested $4 million to help Lewis start his brokerage in 1980 _ was never charged, and there is no proof that it or Lewis profited from the manipulation. But under federal securities laws, profit isn't necessary to commit a crime. Lewis maintained he was not motivated by greed but by a desire to punish rival speculators attempting to bid down the price of Fireman's Fund in anticipation of the new stock offering. The government disagreed. ``Lewis' attempts to portray himself as a misguided watchdog of the markets are simply not supported by the facts, which show instead a straightforward market manipulation designed to assist a close business associate, American Express,'' prosecutors said in court papers. Columbia University securities law professor John C. Coffee Jr. said Lewis' contention that no one was harmed in the manipulation was misplaced. ``People were buying these securities as a price that was inflated and artificial,'' he said. Prosecutors alleged that at Lewis' request, Jefferies bought more than 400,000 shares of Fireman's Fund on May 8, 1986, successfully driving its price up 12{ cents to $38 a share. A day later, American Express announced it would sell 8 million shares of its 41 percent-owned Fireman's Fund at $41.50 a share, a new stock offering that had been widely expected. Prosecutors said American Express made $88 million from the sale but they never offered evidence that any of that profit was tainted by what Lewis did.
